name: 2-chloro-5-trifluoromethylpyridine
Reason: The basic unit, pyridine, has a melting point around -42°C. The introduction of a chlorine atom typically raises the melting point due to the increase in polarizability and possible dipole-dipole interactions; this effect can be estimated at +50°C. The trifluoromethyl group also raises the melting point due to its strong electronegativity, which contributes to dipole-dipole interactions, as well as its size increasing the molecular weight; its effect might be estimated at around +25°C. Combining these effects, we calculate the expected change in melting point as a sum of the contributions from each substituent.
